query: What are the best techniques and scores achieved in Santa 2025 Kaggle Christmas tree packing competition as of January 2026?

results.title: ANSWER
results.text: As of January 2026, the best scores achieved in the Santa 2025 Kaggle Christmas Tree Packing competition are around 68.89 to 68.92, with top teams like "Jingle bins," "shr," and "KiRaRe" reaching scores in this range ([Kaggle leaderboard](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025/leaderboard), [discussion from 01/02/2026](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025/discussion/665669)). The highest reported score is approximately 68.92.

results.title: Christmas tree production in the United States - Wikipedia
results.text:
[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#bodyContent)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

A [Robinson R44 Raven II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robinson_R44) helicopter lifting Christmas trees using a belly hook, a long line, and a remote hook at a Christmas tree farm in Oregon

While the first [Christmas tree farm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christmas_tree_farm) may have appeared as early as 1901, **Christmas tree production in the United States** was largely limited to what could be harvested from natural forests until the 1950s. Among the important Christmas tree producing areas in the U.S. are [Wisconsin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wisconsin), [North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Carolina), [Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania) and the [Pacific Northwest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Northwest). In 2002 [Christmas tree production](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christmas_tree_production) in the United States totaled 20.8 million trees and the U.S. was one of the world's leading producers of natural [Christmas trees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christmas_trees). That same year, Pennsylvania was the top producer in the United States.

## History

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Christmas_tree_production_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=1)\]

The first Christmas tree farm in the United States is believed to have begun in 1888 when George E. Wagner founded the Wagner Tree Farm on 1,700 acres near Pocono Lake, PA. He and his son, Sterling R. Wagner, achieved recognition in the fields of forestry and conservation. A WB&E rail spur provided an outlet for forest products, coal, blueberries, and 1,500 Christmas trees annually. " [\[1\]](https://www.hmdb.org/m.asp?m=97721)" Despite the early pioneers of the industry, by the late 1940s 90 percent of all natural Christmas trees sold in the United States were still harvested from forests. The most popular species during that era, [Balsam Fir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balsam_Fir), [Douglas-fir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas-fir), [Black Spruce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Spruce) and [White Spruce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_Spruce), were all readily available from forests.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-chastagner-1)

Following World War II more trees began to be planted in [plantations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plantation). Other changes were taking place as well, in the late 1940s and early 1950s farmers began to shear trees in response to customer demand for denser trees.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-chastagner-1) During the 1960s the market for [Christmas trees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christmas_trees) in the United States began to change. The number of part-time growers declined, while some part-time growers ceased operations others expanded their operations and became full-time Christmas tree farmers. Expansion occurred in all major U.S. Christmas tree growing regions, [Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan), the [Pacific Northwest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Northwest) and [North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Carolina).[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-msu-2)

The number of plantings increased during the late 1970s and continued to do so into the 1980s.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-msu-2) From 1977 to 1979 total U.S. production reached about 29 million Christmas trees annually.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-rma-3) One species, [Scots Pine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scots_Pine) was planted in numbers which far exceeded [demand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demand) for the product. As the number of individual farmers increased, better marketing strategies and promotion programs were developed.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-msu-2) [Helicopters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helicopter) became a fixture on large farms during the early 1980s as growers used them to move trees from the field to the shipping yard.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-chastagner-1) Between 1988 and 1994 U.S. the number of Christmas trees harvested in the U.S. was about 34–36 million per year.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-rma-3)

Christmas tree farm in Texas

In 2002, in the United States, 21,904 Christmas tree farms covered 447,000 acres (1,810 km2) of cropland and accounted for 20.8 million Christmas trees cut.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-usda1-4) Of those farms, 686 harvested 100 acres (0.40 km2) or more, which accounted for over 196,000 of the total acres of trees harvested. That same year, there were only three U.S. Christmas tree farms with more than 10,000 acres (40 km2) of cropland in production.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-usda1-4) Pennsylvania was home to the most American Christmas tree farms in 2002; the state boasted 2,164 farms. [Oregon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon), however, had the most acreage devoted to the crop with 67,800 acres being used for Christmas tree farming.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-census05-5)

The total U.S. crop in 2004 was valued at $506 million with $143 million attributed to the nation's leading producer in 2004, Oregon.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-census05-5) Oregon was followed in production numbers by North Carolina, [Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_(state)), and Michigan.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-census05-5)

## North Carolina

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Christmas_tree_production_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=2)\]

In 2002 about 2.9 million Christmas trees were harvested in the state of North Carolina, second behind only Oregon in terms of trees cut.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-usda1-4) By 2004 the crop in North Carolina was worth more than $100 million.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-ncda-6) The North Carolina Department of Agriculture stated that 18% of natural Christmas tree harvested in the United States come from the 42 million trees planted by 1,500 growers in the states.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-ncda-6)

## Pacific Northwest

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Christmas_tree_production_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=3)\]

A Christmas tree lot in the suburbs of Portland, Oregon

Oregon and Washington are among the most important U.S. states in the production of Christmas trees. 92% of the crop produced in this region consists of Douglas fir and Noble fir species.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Facts_at_a_Glance-7) Other species produced in this region include grand fir, balsam fir, Nordmann fir, Colorado blue spruce and Norway spruce trees.

Currently approximately 92% of Christmas trees grown in the Pacific Northwest are exported out of the region. California is the largest market for Pacific Northwest Christmas trees, purchasing 45% of the crop. Other large foreign export destinations include China, Japan, Mexico and Philippines.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Facts_at_a_Glance-7)

In 2015, Oregon had approximately 700 Christmas tree farms with a combined 63,000 acres, yielding 7.2 million Christmas trees valued at approximately $120 million. The majority of Christmas tree production occurs in the Willamette Valley region including Benton, Clackamas, Marion, Polk and Yamhill counties.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Facts_at_a_Glance-7)

In 2015, Washington State had approximately 250 Christmas tree farms with a combined 23,000 acres, yielding 2.3 mi...

results.title: iRubric: Recycled Christmas Tree Competition rubric - C2W6643
results.text: iRubric: Recycled Christmas Tree Competition rubric - C2W6643 [Skip to main content](#pageContentCoreContainer) [**](javascript:void(0);) ******************** [**](https://help.rcampus.com/index.php?title=RUBRICS_STUDIO) # iRubric: Recycled Christmas Tree Competition rubric find rubric|| [![search](images/icons/16/search.gif "search")](javascript:document.formrubricsearcheditc_cfm_mini.submit()) | | | [](javascript:void(0);) [edit](rubriceditf.cfm?code=C2W6643)[print](rubricprinteditc.cfm?purpose=customize&code=C2W6643)[share](javascript:void(0);)[Copy to my rubrics](rubriccopyeditf.cfm?code=C2W6643&purpose=copy&)[Bookmark](favoriteeditc.cfm?rt=26&rid=C2W6643&t=Recycled%20Christmas%20Tree%20Competition&)[test run](rubricgradeeditf.cfm?purpose=edit&code=C2W6643&s=yes&framed=yes)[assess...](Assessmenteditc.cfm?code=C2W6643&type=rubric)delete[**Do more...](#rubric_ToolBox) | Recycled Christmas Tree Competition[](javascript:void(0);) **[Recycled Christmas Tree Competition](rubricshowc.cfm?sp=yes&code=P2W55WW&) This rubric will be used to judge the recycled Christmas tree competition. \*\*\*Guidelines: Use recyclable items or things from around the household, school compound or community. The height of the tree must be 4-5 feet. **Rubric Code:**C2W6643** **By[Analeechuc1996]() **Ready to use **Public Rubric **Subject:[Education](rubricshellc.cfm?sid=33&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) **Type:[Project](rubricshellc.cfm?gcid=3&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) **Grade Levels:K-5, 6-8, 9-12 [**](javascript:void(0);) [**Desktop Mode](javascript:void(0);&)[**Mobile Mode](javascript:void(0);&) [![Powered by iRubric](images/rubric2/iRubric_poweredby.gif "Powered by iRubric")](https://www.irubric.com)Recycled Christmas Decor | |**20 points each** **4 pts** |**15 points each** **3 pts** |**10 points each** **2 pts** |**5 point each** **1 pts** |**SCORE** **(N/A)** | Visual Impact "Best Overall" | 20 points each "In Awe!" "Fabulous" "Merry and Bright!" 15 points each "Job well done!" "Nice job!" 10 points each "Good, I can see where they were going with the theme." 5 point each "What?" "I don't get it." SCORE Craftmanship | 20 points each Exceptionally attractive. Well constructed and neat. Craftsmanship/skills are excellent. Exclusive and very creative use of recycled items. 15 points each Attractive in terms of neatness. Good construction and not very messy. Craftsmanship/skills are good. Majority of items were recycled . Creative use of items. 10 points each The Christmas Tree is acceptably attractive though it may be a bit messy. Craftsmanship/skills are average. Some items were recyclable. 5 point each Distractingly messy Craftsmanship/skills are poor. Few or no items were recyclable. SCORE Completeness and Durability | 20 points each Well completed, very durable and ready for the exhibition. 15 points each Completed, durable but some items seem out of place. | 10 points each Output is somewhat complete. Missing something that results to lack of durability. | 5 point each Output was attempted or not complete nor durable. | SCORE | Originality "Most Creative" | 20 points each Exceptional use of new ideas and originality to create decoration. “Christmas tree to be awe - original ideas” | 15 points each Good use of new ideas and originality to create decoration. | 10 points each Average use of new ideas and originality to create decoration. | 5 point each No use of new ideas and originality to create decoration. | SCORE | Christmas Theme Fun, eye-catching, communicates Christmas theme | 20 points each Decor is very good, fun, eye- catching and communicates Christmas theme fully- in your own original idea. | 15 points each Decor is good and presentable that meets Christmas Theme well. | 10 points each Decor is average and common in Christmas theme. | 5 point each Decor does not communicate Christmas theme fully. | SCORE | Materials Use of recycle materials in or around school compound. | 20 points each The use of plastic bottles, tin cans, wood, plastic bags, stoppers, plastic wrappers, straws, ect., to be use on the tree. The tree 95% have recycle materials. | 15 points each The tree consist of 75% recycle material. | 10 points each The tree consist of 50% recycle material | 5 point each The tree consist of 25% recycle materials. | SCORE | Oral presentation Presentation of the recycle Christmas tree | 20 points each Students Explain the process of the tree, the purpose, the theme, what will happen to materials after displaying the tree. 1. Collecting materials. 2. Cleaning material. 3. Christmas tree theme 4. The use of materials after the tree is displayed. | 15 points each Students explained the recycle Christmas tree and process but something was missing. | 10 points each Presentation was vague, not all information was presented. | 5 point each Presentation was all over the place - didn’t understand the steps of how the tree was actually made. | SCORE | Keywords: * competition Christmas Subjects: * [Arts and Design](rubricshellc.cfm?si=2&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) * [Business](rubricshellc.cfm?si=4&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) * [Health](rubricshellc.cfm?si=16&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) * [Math](rubricshellc.cfm?si=21&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) * [Education](rubricshellc.cfm?si=33&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) * [(General)](rubricshellc.cfm?si=1000&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) Types: * [Project](rubricshellc.cfm?gcid=3&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) * [Presentation](rubricshellc.cfm?gcid=5&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) * [Assignment](rubricshellc.cfm?gcid=8&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) * [ePortfolio](rubricshellc.cfm?gcid=12&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) * [(Other)](rubricshellc.cfm?gcid=100&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) [**Discuss this rubric](https://www.rcampus.com/rubricmsgboardc.cfm?code=C2W6643&) You may also be interested in: [**More rubrics by this author]() [**More Arts and Design rubrics](rubricshellc.cfm?si=2&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) [**More Project rubrics](rubricshellc.cfm?gcid=3&mode=gallery&sms=publicrub&) Do more with this rubric: [Preview](rubricshowc.cfm?code=C2W6643&sp=yes&) [![Preview](https://www.rcampus.com/images/icons/48/view.gif)](rubricshowc.cfm?code=C2W6643&sp=yes&) Preview this rubric. [Edit](rubriceditf.cfm?code=C2W6643&) [![Edit](https://www.rcampus.com/images/icons/48/rubricstudio.gif)](rubriceditf.cfm?code=C2W6643&) Modify this rubric. [Copy](rubriccopyeditf.cfm?code=C2W6643&purpose=copy&) [![Copy](https://www.rcampus.com/images/icons/48/copy.gif)](rubriccopyeditf.cfm?code=C2W6643&purpose=copy&) Make a copy of this rubric and begin editing the copy.
